title: Sectorial Specialisation of OECD member countries.
authors: Figure 1. Sectorial Specialisation of OECD member countries. General view of the Sankey diagram. Donor countries are shown on the left, and sectors funded on the right. The streams represent the flow of bilateral adaptation aid from the countries to the sectors. Source : OECD StatExtracts. Date : Jan 6 2014

sections.html:
Short-caption

This interactive map shows the distribution across sectors and specific areas of the bilateral adaptation aid committed by each OECD member country between 2010 and 2012. Filters can be applied so as to visualize the top donor country for each sector/specific area, and the top sector/specific area for each donor country.

The viewer can explore the shared concerns of OECD member countries, as well as their sectorial specialisation : what areas do OECD member countries think are worth being fostered by their action ? Do some donor countries “own” particular areas ? How donor countries interpret what adaptation is about?

Some specificities appear clearly : the United Kingdom seems specialized in biodiversity, France in water supply and sanitation, Germany in agriculture etc.

General overview

The general overview associates flows of adaptation aid committed by OECD member countries (represented on the left side of the graph) to the different sectors (on the middle of the graph). Each sector is then distributed along its specific areas (on the right side). The thickness of the streams are proportional to the amount of money, thus showing which sectors and specific areas receive more or less funding.

The viewer can chose to see only countries versus sectors, countries versus specific areas, or sectors versus specific areas.

Filter “top sector/specific area”

The viewer can also apply a filter to show the top sector or specific area for each OECD member country, i.e. the sector/area that receives more money from each donor. This view enables to simplify the general overview to show global trend, and see what the main concern of each donor country is, and whether they share it with other countries or not.

Filter “top country”

The viewer can apply a filter to show the top donor country for each sector or specific area.

This view enables to identify the extant of the concerns of the different OECD members : how large is the span of their action ? Are there very different interpretation of what adaptation is about ?
sections.title: How to read the map

sections.html:
The data are extracted from the OECD StatExtracts database (stats.oecd.org) which collects general Official Development Assistance (ODA) and is reported OECD Development Assistance Committee by member countries. We identified aid that was labelled through the RioMarkers and selected only projects that had been categorised with adaptation as their principal objective (score 2).  As the RioMarker “adaptation” was implemented in 2010, we have only used data beginning from that year in order to identify adaptation-related projects. We summed the amounts of USD committed and adjusted for inflation for the three years between 2010 and 2012.

We then extracted the sector names and purpose names which are standardised fields for each of the project in the OECD database: according to http://www.oecd.org/dac/stats/purposecodessectorclassification.htm, “sector coding identifies the specific areas of the recipient’s economic or social development the transfer intends to foster.” We labelled the first level categories as “sectors” and the subcategories as “specific areas”

We took out the purpose names that had a total amount of less than $2 million and were used by less than three countries. We also deleted the “unallocated/unspecified” purpose.
